BikingTrails.name: Prineville Resevoir campground trail
BikingTrails.description: Great single track. Rock and steeper inclines with some off camber parts of the trail make for some good technical riding. You can actually ride from Prineville Oregon State campground to Juniper point and catch another section of trail that has crushed rock and is about 3' wide.
BikingTrails.directions: Go to prineville res. Trail is on north east side of res.

BikingTrails.name: Parkway
BikingTrails.description: Descending trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Escape from Moscow
BikingTrails.description: Descending trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Horse Ridge Recreation Area
BikingTrails.description: Excellent riding.
BikingTrails.directions: From Highway 20 and 3rd street in Bend, Oregon, drive east 17.9 miles to the Oregon Badlands Wilderness sign, turn hard right and proceed 0.7 miles to the Horse Ridge Trailhead.

BikingTrails.name: Sand Canyon
BikingTrails.description: Popular descending trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: 66 Trail System
BikingTrails.description: Easy loops plus a mountain bike skills area. Two new trails opened Oct 1, 2019.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Lookout Mountain
BikingTrails.description: Beautiful remote mountain tops and great climbing. The down hill is amazing.
BikingTrails.directions: From Prineville go east on 26. Turn right on Ochoco Creek Rd.Ranger station on parking on left and right before the fork. Ride to the top on the road and enter the trail at independence trail.

BikingTrails.name: Boyd Cave Trail
BikingTrails.description: Open sage and sparse forest with vistas of the Three Sisters to the west and Newberry Buttes to the south. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: Trail is accessed from Swamp Wells North Trail #3961 or Coyote Loop Trail #3962.

BikingTrails.name: Coyote Loop Trail
BikingTrails.description: Open sage and sparse forest with vistas of the Three Sisters to the northwest. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: Trail is accessed from the Swamp Wells Trail #3961 near Horse Butte, or from Swamp Wells Horse Camp.

BikingTrails.name: Arnold Ice Cave
BikingTrails.description: This trail travels from Coyote Loop Trail #3962.0 to Swamp Wells Campground.  The Skeleton Cave Trail #3963.1 and the Fuzztail Butte Trail #3965 are accessed from this trail.
BikingTrails.directions: Southeast of Bend off Horse Butte Rd.

BikingTrails.name: Horse Butte
BikingTrails.description: Trails in this area are good for those who want a less crowded alternative to the busy trails west of Bend. Please be considerate of other users since these trails are designated primarily for horse riders. via USDA
BikingTrails.directions: Located just south of Bend, Horse Butte is a handy hub for trails that allow for the exploration of the north part of the old Fort Rock Ranger District.

BikingTrails.name: Swamp Wells Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail extends from near Horse Butte, just south of Bend, to the north rim of Newberry Caldera.  source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: Southeast of Bend.

BikingTrails.name: Crater Rim Trail
BikingTrails.description: Paulina Peak with an elevation of 7,984 feet, is about 4,000 feet higher than the terrain surrounding the volcano. There is a gravel fire road that winds to the top. This is a gruelling climb for someone from New Jersey like me,, an 8000 foot elevation. Air please ! The trail head starts about 1000 feet from the peak. It is a pretty tight sigletrack for approximatley 19 miles.The end of the trail dumps you right in the parking lot where you left your car. To get to the top of Paulina's Peak,, is about 7 miles from the parking lot up the gravel fire road. So,, approx 25-26 miles total.. You have to climb to the top to see the views. This is not a technical ride by any means,, it is just a great workout and quite a scenic tour. The trail is mostly rolling hills,, up and down,, few roots from trees to go over,, and lots of cinder and volcanic ash all over. Soft terrain. The last 3-4 miles is a downhill bomber,, with a few rail road tie sized wood to jump over. Then that dumps right out into the parking lot.  Nice ride.
BikingTrails.directions: Located in the town of Newberry Crater,, Paulina's Peak, Newberry Volcano, centered about 20 miles southeast of Bend, Oregon.  From Bend,, take 97 south,, left on Paulina East Lake Road,, take this to NF 2120,  slight right to NF 500,, becomes an unamed road,,  slight left onto Newberry Crater Road,  your there...1 hour,, 15 minutes from Bend, 38 miles.

BikingTrails.name: Parallel Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail is located within the Newberry National Volcanic Monument and connects to the Newberry Crater Trail No. 3958, and the Crater Rim Trail No. 3957.  The connector trails are recommended to separate horse use from auto traffic on Forest Road 21, east of East Lake. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: This trail can be accessed from the Newberry Crater Trail No. 3958 or the Crater Rim Trail No. 3957.

BikingTrails.name: C.O.D.
BikingTrails.description: This trail roughly parallels Century Drive, but it is WAY more fun than riding pavement! This is great Bend singletrack: mostly buff, dry, dusty singletrack. It connects to the Storm king trail on the westernmost end and to the Elfin Magic and KGB  trails.
BikingTrails.directions: Part of the Phil's Trails trail system. This trail roughly parallels Century Drive.

BikingTrails.name: Tiddlywinks
BikingTrails.description: Tiddlywinks starts at the snow park trailhead (see Google Maps location) and has a short, rolling climb, and then begins to descend! Most of this trail is a gradual, rolling descent with classic buff Bend singletrack. However, there are a few killer sections thrown in, including a half-mile long flow section of downhill with tons of berms, jumps (rollable or boostable), and just flow, flow, flow! This specific section isn't marked on any of the maps... just ride Tiddlywinks and you'll find it.Tiddlywinks connects to the Funner Trail, Storm King Trail, and the C.O.D. Trail (a part of Phil's).
BikingTrails.directions: Near Bend, see Google Map

BikingTrails.name: Maston Trail
BikingTrails.description: Up and down singletrack with a few rock gardens to test skill.  There's a wonderful view of the Deschutes River at one point.
BikingTrails.directions: From Redmond, head west toward Sisters.  Turn left on Cline Falls Rd.  There are a couple of trailheads.  One on the left a few miles after the left turn and another one a bit farther.

BikingTrails.name: Juniper Trailhead
BikingTrails.description: An easy going, sandy trail. With a few technical areas. Some gradual climb...that stretches maybe a few miles. Lots of mini whoops.  Easy going and fun for most beginners.
BikingTrails.directions: From Redmond go out 126 w. towrard Sisters. Herald the Eagle crest exit on the right just after the bridge and overpass. Head south on Cline Falls hwy for about 3-4 miles. Juniper trailhead is clearly marked on the left with parking.

BikingTrails.name: no name
BikingTrails.description: Mixture single and double track
BikingTrails.directions: past Taylor NW off of Bullsprings logging rd.

BikingTrails.name: Kents to Phils, chicken, KGB, Marvins
BikingTrails.description: Kents, to Phils down Phils to chicken out KGB just below switch back climb connector to Marvins, Marvins back to Tr hd
BikingTrails.directions: Phils trail head

BikingTrails.name: Upper Whoops
BikingTrails.description: Singletrack with lots of berms and some jumps.
BikingTrails.directions: Phils trailhead

BikingTrails.name: Entrada Loop Trail
BikingTrails.description: Nice for day hiking, or as a mountain bike connector to either the Tumalo Trail System or the Deschutes River Trail. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: Located southwest of Bend.

BikingTrails.name: Newberry Crater Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail is located within the Newberry National Volcanic Monument.  It crosses the floor of Newberry Caldera from the Crater Rim Trail near Cinder Hill, to the Crater Rim Trail near the entrance station at Paulina Lake.  This trail is an easy way to shorten a trip around the Crater Rim Trail.  It also connects into the Lost Lake Trail No. 3958.2 and Parallel Trail No. 3958.3. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: This trail can be accessed from the Crater Rim Trail No. 3957, Big Obsidian Flow Trailhead, and from the Chief Paulina Horse Camp.

BikingTrails.name: The Lair
BikingTrails.description: The Lair is one of the premiere bike parks in Oregon. Designed, built, and maintained by volunteers from the Central Oregon Trail Alliance (COTA), the park was built in collaboration with the Forest Service and is located entirely on Forest Service land. Like many of the other park on this list, it is a progression park and features everything from three-foot beginner jumps to 20-foot monsters. While the park has been lovingly sculpted into an excellent resource, the volunteers can always use more help. If you come out to a riding spot and see people digging, ask if you can help. More help would enable things to get done faster, and also allow for more time to improve on what's already in place, said Joe Treinen of COTA.
BikingTrails.directions: Directions to The Lair:Located just off the urban growth boundry West of Tetherow.Lat. 44° 1'36.19″N  Long. 121°22'23.15″W44.026366, -121.372232 From Skyliners Road west of Bend, turn south on Road 4606, the road to Phil's Trailhead.  Continue on the paved road past the trailhead. When the pavement ends, take a left on the gravel road. The road becomes a white pumice road. Stay on the road for approximately two miles to a small parking area at The Lair.

BikingTrails.name: Cole loop
BikingTrails.description: Climb the cole loop.
BikingTrails.directions: Henderson Flats OHV Trails, over the fence.

BikingTrails.name: Deschutes River
BikingTrails.description: This trail follows the western side of the Deschutes River for the first 12.5 miles then crosses to the Sun River side. Heading south on this trail is traveling upstream on the river thus some elevation is gained, about 300 ft going this direction. This is a very well planned and built trail that runs through several park areas along the river that can be very busy with other users at times. Most all of these areas are accessed off of Road 41 and offer numerous starting points. Along the section between the Big Eddy Rec site and Dillon Falls (about 2.5 miles) there are a couple different routes all marked by different signage, there are also maps at all the kiosks along the way. Although the route nearest the river is always open to MTB through here it is encouraged to use the alternate MTB route during high use times- summer weekends, holidays, etc.The trail itself is a great singletrack that climbs and descends ridges as it follows the river. There is a little technical area within the first couple miles but after that it is a fantastic novice/intermediate ride through the woods. Scenery along the way is incredible, with many waterfalls, lava rock formations and wildlife to see. As you near Benham Falls there are a couple trails heading west away from the river, these climb up to Benham Butte and beyond. Following the river trail past Benham Falls brings you to a footbridge across the river and another 2.5 miles of great trail to Sun River. A left turn after the footbridge will lead along the Blackrock trail through the lava fields 4 miles to the Lava Lands Visitor Center on Highway 97.
BikingTrails.directions: From Bend drive west on Highway 46 towards Mt Bachelor. At mile 5 Bachelor View dr is on the left, this is a private dr however there is room for a few vehicles near the entrance, trail takes off west under the power line. Option #2; at mile 5.5 turn left into small, dirt parking area. Popular with dog walkers and joggers there are a few different trails that start here but all lead over the ridge and down to the river- follow the one with most bike tracks.The other end of this trail is well marked within the Golf Community of Sun River, south of Bend.

BikingTrails.name: Phil's Trail
BikingTrails.description: Since this is the namesake for the entire trail system and the oldest trail in the area, I kind of expected a blown-out doubletrack. That is entirely NOT the case! COTA has done an amazing job of maintenance, and this trail is in absolutely excellent condition! Over the years, Phil's has gained an absolutely incredible flow that makes for a very fast, pedally descent.
BikingTrails.directions: Phil's Trailhead

BikingTrails.name: Mrazek
BikingTrails.description: Accessed from Shevlin Park, this trail was created by bikers for bikers so is a Good entertaining ride.  The trail weaves non-stop until its connection with Metolius-Windigo Trail or junctions to Tumalo falls. Mrazek trail primarily runs through old clear cuts of various ages.  Use this trail as the beginning or end of a long loop with other rides in the Phils trail system connected by the Metolius-Windigo connector.
BikingTrails.directions: The trail begins at the far end of the Shevlin Park Loop Trail, which is located west of Bend in Shevlin Park, off of Shevlin Park Road. Ride the single-track southwest through Shevlin Park about 2.1 miles, to connect with Mrazek. You can also connect to the trail along forest roads around Tumalo Falls and Shevlin Park.

BikingTrails.name: Ben's Upper
BikingTrails.description: Ben's is about 7 miles long one-way, and is split into basically two portions. The lower portion is all two-way, flowy cross country trail, but the upper section of Ben's is where the action is at! Climb up the gravel road, and drop into the downhill-only upper portion. Get ready for a sick 1.7-mile long section of endless jumps and huge berms.Flow trail to the max!
BikingTrails.directions: Start at the Phil's Trailhead

BikingTrails.name: Ben's Lower
BikingTrails.description: Ben's is about 7 miles long one-way, and is split into basically two portions. The lower portion is all two-way, flowy cross country trail, but the upper section of Ben's is downhill-only.
BikingTrails.directions: Phils trailhead

BikingTrails.name: Phil's Area
BikingTrails.description: Update 7/22/13 by mtbgreg1:The Phil's Area Trail System is the go-to trail system for mountain biking in Bend. Even the other trails in the region that aren't actually part of the Phil's Trail System feed into or connect to trails that feed into Phil's.According to the locals, and for the purpose of our trail listings, the boundaries of the Phil's Area Trail System is a square comprised of Skyliners Road to the north, Highway 46 (Cascade Lakes Scenic Byway) to the south, Bend to the east, and the Storm King trail to the west.This complex trail system offers a variety of different trails, but on average the trails are very buff, very flowy, with some great corners to rail. The trail tread is quite loose and sandy, and gets very dry, especially late in the season, leading to moon dust conditions. Here and there you'll find some rock gardens, skinnies, and sections of flow trail with big jumps and massive berms! All of the difficult sections do feature ride arounds, making this an extremely beginner-friendly area.
BikingTrails.directions: Drive or ride west of Bend about 2.5 miles on Skyliner's Road until you reach a paved road on your left. Go 0.5 mile on this road and park at Phil's Trailhead and begin the loop.

BikingTrails.name: Cascade View Trails
BikingTrails.description: Stacked loop trail system with beginner, intermediate, and advanced options.
BikingTrails.directions: Cascade View trailhead is located off Eagle Crest Blvd, Redmond, OR 97756.

BikingTrails.name: Catch and release
BikingTrails.description: Most of Catch and release is a nice flowing single track that is easy to ride. At the south end there are some rock sections that add a little fun to the route.  This is a great way to get back ton Century, or back to town without having to ride the road.
BikingTrails.directions: Catch and release starts at the end of Tyler's Traverse.  From there you ride north to Century Blvd and the intersection of Conklin.  It's a route that roughly follows Conklin and gives you a little more single track. Without having to deal with car traffic.

BikingTrails.name: Ticket to Ride
BikingTrails.description: A 6-mile beginner loop at the Forest Service Welcome Center off the Cascades Lake Highway. This trail is also compatible with adaptive cycles.
BikingTrails.directions: OR

BikingTrails.name: Inn Loop
BikingTrails.description: A moderately easy ride through some nice stands of lodgepole pine and ponderosa pine.
BikingTrails.directions: Drive or ride 7 miles west of Bend on Hwy 46 (Cascade Lakes Hwy) until you reach FS road 41, which is the first paved road on your left after passing the Inn of the 7th Mountain. Park in the small parking area at the junction of FS 41 and Hwy 46.

BikingTrails.name: Storm King
BikingTrails.description: A fun trail by itself however is mainly used as access too or in conjunction with others as loop routes etc. Running N-S across the face of the Mtn slope there is not a lot of climbing over its length but it does have some elevation gain from S to N as it climbs to the Helicopter Pad. From Conklin rd it’s a 4 mile, very gradual climb through the forest up to the intersection with Funner and then highway 46 a half mile later. Across the highway it intersects with the top of C.O.D. and the Grand Slam 2 miles farther, all this way being a challenging route through the forest and scattered lava rock gardens. Two more miles and some climbing bring you to the Heli Pad and several choices back down or farther up the mountain if you choose.
BikingTrails.directions: South end; head West from Bend on highway 46 to a left turn onto Conklin rd. a couple miles down watch for parking on the left side and the trailhead on the right. No real signage but this is a popular starting point so its fairly obvious.Can also be access where it crosses highway 46 aprox 3 miles past Conklin rd although parking here is limited.Trail terminates at an intersection with Phil’s trail near Whoops and Ben’s trails at whats known as the Helicopter Pad.

BikingTrails.name: Tumalo Trail System
BikingTrails.description: Massive trail system located west of Bend in the national forest.
BikingTrails.directions: Multiple trailheads accessible from just west of Bend.

BikingTrails.name: Pine Drops
BikingTrails.description: Pine Drops is a newly-legalized trail that adds two miles to the Phil's Area trail system.
BikingTrails.directions: OR

BikingTrails.name: Peter Skene Ogden
BikingTrails.description: This trailhead is located on Paulina Creek and provides access to the Peter Skene Ogden Trail.
BikingTrails.directions: From Bend, travel 23.5 miles south on Hwy 97, then 2.8 miles east on County Road 21.

BikingTrails.name: Larsen Trail
BikingTrails.description: The Larsen Trail runs for 3 miles one-way from Kiwa Springs to the Tiddlywinks Trail. It parallels USFS road 4130 for most of the way. Intermediate difficulty.
BikingTrails.directions: Start near Kiwa Springs

BikingTrails.name: Tumalo Creek
BikingTrails.description: The Tumalo Creek Trail is 3.5 miles one-way and parallels Skyliner road. Starting at the Skyliner trailhead, the trail runs up near the road on the ridge side to the Tumalo Falls trailhead. Since it costs $$ to park at Tumalo Falls but parking at Skyliner is free, this is a great trail to start on.The singletrack itself is pretty easy: classic dusty Bend singletrack. There are a few gradual climbs and descents, but nothing serious. The trail does provide some pretty sweet views of the mountains above and the creek below.
BikingTrails.directions: Skyliner Trailhead

BikingTrails.name: Tylers Traverse
BikingTrails.description: Flowing Singletrack with mostly separated up and down hill trails. A local favourite.
BikingTrails.directions: Junction of kiwa Butte trail and Dinah-Moe-Humm trial

BikingTrails.name: Skyliners
BikingTrails.description: Skyliners is a 3.2-mile intermediate singletrack trail that runs from the Skyliner's trailhead to a junction with Whoops and Ben's trail, which is the corner of the Phil's Area Trail System. This provides a crucial singletrack connection to other singletrack trails higher up the mountain, allowing you to do a massive mountain ride!
BikingTrails.directions: Start at the Skyliners trailhead off of Skyliners road

BikingTrails.name: Wanoga Sno-Park Fat Bike Trails
BikingTrails.description: There are two groomed fat bike loops here. One is a 9-mile advanced loop and one is a 3-mile beginner, shorter loop.
BikingTrails.directions: OR

BikingTrails.name: Funner
BikingTrails.description: As the name suggest, this one is a blast. Can be ridden both ways but is really designed for riding top down starting at the Wanoga sno-park. The first mile has quite a bit of big ring riding as it winds its way across a fairly flat plateau before it drops downhill. Large banked corners through the trees keep things exciting and as with any trail around Bend riders must always be ready for the ‘all of a sudden’ lava rock garden to pop up out of nowhere. Once this trail drops down the hill it is full of twists, turns, drops and several man made features. Most anything particularly challenging will have a ‘ride around’ option for those not comfortable with the challenge. This trail terminates at an intersection with the Storm King and Tiddlywinks trails. One possible route is to ride up Tiddlywinks to the Wanoga sno-park and down Funner.
BikingTrails.directions: Main access is from the Wanoga Sno-park aprox. 14 miles West of Bend on highway 46 (Mt Bachelor highway). There are a couple trails leaving this parking lot, Funner is trail leaving the East end. at the far end of the pump track.Can also be accessed from the Storm King trail near its intersection w/Highway 46.

BikingTrails.name: Swede Ridge Loop
BikingTrails.description: An all singletrack route with great scenery through fun terrain, sharing trails that double as x-country ski trails in the winter. These are singletrack but are wider and flatter than most MTB trails. There are large brown signs within the Snow Park area marking the ski routes and although good for determining location they can mislead someone on a MTB route, once again a map of the area comes in really handy. Immediately upon setting off from the parking area you will come across a Y and one of these brown signs telling you the Swedes Ridge Loop is to the right- in order to avoid a lot of dirt road riding take a left here and follow the trail 2 miles all the way to the Swampy Lakes Shelter, passing a few other singletracks along the way. The trail leading north behind the shelter will lead you down 1000â€™ to the Tumalo Falls area. Staying on the Swedes Ridge Loop the trail from here gets tighter and more technical. Stay left at the next intersection (signed) and follow the trail 2 miles out the ridge on a fast & twisty trail with plenty of opportunities for viewing the surrounding mountains and canyon below. The trail suddenly stops at a FS road at the ridges point, lots of good views here. There is the option here for continuing on straight all the way down to join in the Philâ€™s Trail Network some 6 miles away. To stay on the Swedes Loop look right as soon as you hit the road, there is an unmarked singletrack disappearing back into the trees not more than 20 yards away. This is another fun section of tight trail through dense trees. Drops, switchbacks and a couple man-made skinnies await the rider along this 1.5 mile section until the route joins back in with a ski trail. Another 1.5 miles farther and you come to a 4-way intersection, go straight through this for another half mile and you come back to the main trail that heads to Swampy Lakes Shelter you started on, go left and its 1 fun mile back down to the parking area.
BikingTrails.directions: Drive or ride 16 miles west of Bend on Hwy 46 (Cascade Lakes Hwy) to the Swampy Lakes Sno-Park and park here. The route begins at the north end of the parking lot across from the restrooms.

BikingTrails.name: Dinah Moe Humm
BikingTrails.description: This trail starts at Edison Butte Sno-park and will connect to Kiwa Butte trail and gives access to Tyler's Traverse. This trail can be used as a shuttle trip connecting to the deschutes river trail and back to Sunriver or bend. The Trail starts with a moderate climb ~1.5 miles then levels off for another 1.5 miles. The trail then starts a fairly steep climb for approximately 1 mile to the top of a butte. There is a nice look out with good views of Mt Bachelor. The trail carries on for another several miles until connecting with Tylers traverse and Kiwa Butte. The trail is 7.6 miles to the junction.Overall the trail is well maintained and has moderate flow. Overall the trail has little technical features but does over several lava rock gardens.
BikingTrails.directions: Trailhead is at Edison butte sno-park. Coming from Bend take cascade lakes hwy to Or-45. Sno park will be on the Right in 4 miles. The trail is across from Or-45.

BikingTrails.name: Madras East Hills
BikingTrails.description: This is a new and still under construction trail system just East of Madras. The area is shared with horse trails but most of the trails are separate from one another. Check out the attached link for COTA (Central Oregon Trail Alliance) https://www.cotamtb.com/madras-east-hills.html
BikingTrails.directions: From downtown Madras take NE B Street East until you pass Juniper Hills Park, parking area will be on right side of the road. https://www.google.com/maps/place/Madras East Hills Trail System/@44.6334179,-121.1081614,15.47z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x54beeb7d191fdbf7:0x62266074e550bd19!8m2!3d44.6352899!4d-121.0907051?hl=en

BikingTrails.name: Farewell
BikingTrails.description: If you climb the North Fork trail, Farewell is a killer descent down the other side of the river, ending up back at Tumalo Falls Trailhead. The singletrack is super flowy, with some very pedally sections up top, eventually steepening into a ripping descent! The trail tread is classic loose, dusty Bend singletrack, so take care. Farewell also offers some gorgeous views of the nearby snowcapped mountains, and some excellent photo ops. Check out the trail photos!(3.5 miles one-way.)
BikingTrails.directions: Tumalo Falls Trailhead

BikingTrails.name: Swampy Dutchman Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail travels from Swampy Lakes Sno-Park to Dutchman Sno-Park.  It is a cross country ski/snowmobile trail that is used as a mountain bike trail in the summer. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: This trail is accessed from Swampy Lakes Sno-Park/Trailhead and/or Dutchman Sno-Park/Trailhead.

BikingTrails.name: North Fork
BikingTrails.description: One of the most scenic rides around the Bend area. *Special note; this is a one way, up hill ride only, so is to be used as access to other trails farther up the mountain. From the parking lot you have fantastic view of the main Tumalo Falls, there are 6 more in the next 3 miles. Trail is a fairly steep grind for the first half mile but mellows out after that and become a fantastic singletrack ride up the canyon all the way to Happy Valley. There are several places to stop and enjoy the view on the way up. Once at Happy Valley this trail ends at the Metolius/Windigo trail making several route options from this point. One popular route and the shortest loop option is to head east on the M/W trail to the Farewell trail that heads back down to the Tumalo Falls trailhead.
BikingTrails.directions: From Bend head west on Skyliners dr 10 miles to bridge over the Tumalo River and the end of the pavement. Another 2 miles will bring you to the end of the road, parking lot and several trailheads.

BikingTrails.name: Swampy Lakes Trail
BikingTrails.description: The Swampy Lakes Trail is a popular way for mountain bikers to get back to Tumalo Falls when doing the North Fork/Metolius-Windigo/Dutchman-Swampy loop around the Bend Municipal Watershed.  Please note, however, that the Watershed itself is closed to mountain bikes, as well as to dogs and horses. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: This trail goes from Swampy Lakes Sno-Park to the Metolius-Windigo Trail in Happy Valley. Trail begins at the Swampy Lakes Sno-Park.

BikingTrails.name: Flagline Trail
BikingTrails.description: The Flagline Trail runs for 9 miles one-way from the Swampy Lakes Sno-Park to Todd Lake. Along the way, the trail runs along/past the base of 7,775-foot Tumalo Mountain.Be aware: this area is closed until August 15th in the summer to protect elk calving grounds.Intermediate difficulty.
BikingTrails.directions: Start at either Swampy Lakes Sno-Park or Todd Lake

BikingTrails.name: Sisters MBT Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail goes south, following old closed roads. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: The trail begins at the Sisters City Park.

BikingTrails.name: Peterson Ridge Loop
BikingTrails.description: X-country riders will love this system. Basically this is an 18 mile loop with no less than 12 â€˜connectorâ€™ trails running between the two sides, PT West & PT East- the ride lengths and different configurations here are almost endless. The local bike shop boasts 28 miles of trails, I guess so if you were to ride them all. The local bike shops and the Forest Service office have free maps available. Like the neighboring systems in Bend all the intersections are marked by a post with a number on it, these correspond with the maps- as you are riding along these #â€™s are not necessarily in order so having a map, at least for the first time here is kind of important.Although not direction specific I chose to ride the loop counter-clockwise (turning right at every intersection) and for the first 2.5 miles the trail was just a twisty, flat ride through the woods, great for the novice riders. After that there was a slight elevation gain and some semi-technical spots mainly in the form of small rock gardens. The views from the ridge of the surrounding mountains are spectacular. At intersection #28, about 8.5 miles from the start you will want to turn left onto PT East, turning right here leads to the Upper Metolius trail- it is possible to ride singletrack from here all the way to the numerous trail systems in Bend. Back on the loop the trail turns very fast and winds its way back down the ridge towards Sisters. Take a left at intersection #2 near the end as going right will take you to the Five Pine Resort (this is plainly marked). There are several FS roads running through this area and you will cross them frequently, however this trail is all singletrack and if you find yourself riding on a road you somehow missed a turn-These are very well planned and built trails and the signage is some of the best I have ever seen on a system this size.
BikingTrails.directions: In Sisters turn south on Elm st and drive about six blocks. Just after a small bridge turn left onto Tyee st and park near the trailhead.

BikingTrails.name: Edison Lava Trail
BikingTrails.description: The Edison Lava Trail runs for 8 miles one-way from the Edison Butte Sno-Park to Lava Lake. It is rated as a black diamond trail, and portions of the trail are shared with ATV traffic. Take the 2.1-mile one-way spur off the trail up to Kwolh Butte for more mileage and a lot more climbing!
BikingTrails.directions: Start at the Edison Butte Sno-Park

BikingTrails.name: LaPine State Park
BikingTrails.description: Very easy tralride, with a few moderate level sections. If you are coming to LaPine state park, you are most likely going for the view. Very beautiful scenery of the Deschutes River, and calm back woods country. Rarely are there people on these trails, so it is a prime spot to get away from it all.
BikingTrails.directions: Coming from bend:Head south on highway 97 for about 22 miles, and turn right onto State Rec Road, there is a large sign pointing you in the direction. Follow State Rec Rd. For three miles, you will arrive at the gates of LaPine state park. Slow down and enter the park, the signs will direct you towards different beginning points.Heading from LaPine:Drive north on highway 97 for 8 miles, you will see the State Park sign, take a left at State Rec Road, follow State Rec Rd. 3 miles and enter into LaPine State Park and follow signs to different beggining points.

BikingTrails.name: Stevens Canyon Loop
BikingTrails.description: Single track, 20 mile loop, adopted from an old motocross loop.
BikingTrails.directions: At Blazin Saddles Bike shop head North on Pine St, Go across Indian Ford Rd, the Turn right on Garrison Butte Rd and first left to: 44.364000,-121.532170

BikingTrails.name: Washington Family Ranch Cyclocross Course
BikingTrails.description: The course starts with a ride down the paved road toward the east, then turns right onto singletrack. After about a quarter-mile on the trail, the route dumps you off near the southeastern corner of the Washington Family Ranch Sports Center and into the start of the cyclocross obstacles.
BikingTrails.directions: Head east from Antelope on Hwy 218 for 3.7 miles (toward the town of Fossil). Turn right onto Cold Camp Road, go 3 miles and turn left on Muddy Road. Drive 11.6 miles to Washington Family Ranch.

BikingTrails.name: Dutchman Flagline Loop
BikingTrails.description: This is an awesome ride.  Only open in its entire length after August 15th each year.  It is really special.
BikingTrails.directions: Drive up Century Drive (46) to Swampy Lakes Snowpark / Trail starts there!  Pick up a map in one of our local bike shops!

BikingTrails.name: Dutchman
BikingTrails.description: Dutchman to Shevlin via Singletrack.
BikingTrails.directions: Start from Dutchman flat sno park, on the N side of Century drive just prior to Bachelor.

BikingTrails.name: Mount Bachelor Bike Park
BikingTrails.description: Mt. Bachelor's Downhill Bike Park, when fully built as approved, will contain more than 13 miles of excavated and single-track downhill mountain bike trails. Trail construction is underway now and is planned to occur each summer until the approved network of trails is complete. The terrain in the Mt. Bachelor Bike Park may contain jumps, hits, wood and dirt ramps, banks, fun boxes, jibs, logs and other constructed or natural features. NOTE: Mt. Bachelor's Downhill Bike Park is currently for intermediate, advanced and expert downhill bikers only. There will not be any beginner trails open until the Lava Flow trail is complete in summer 2014.
BikingTrails.directions: Mount Bachelor Ski Resort
BikingTrails.features: Drinking water, Lift service, Night riding allowed, Restrooms

BikingTrails.name: Wild Canyon Games Mountain Bike Course
BikingTrails.description: The race course starts at the dam on Current Creek Reservoir on Washington Family Ranch property. It starts out traveling west on the paved Muddy Rd and at 3 miles leaves the pavement for 11  miles of doubletrack and fire road navigating. The route ends at the eastern side of the Washington Family Ranch Sports Center.
BikingTrails.directions: Head east from Antelope on Hwy 218 for 3.7 miles (toward the town of Fossil). Turn right onto Cold Camp Road, go 3 miles and turn left on Muddy Road. Drive 11.6 miles to Washington Family Ranch.

BikingTrails.name: Butte Loops Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail consists of two loops: Upper Loop and Lower loop. The Lower Loop is on the low west flank of Black Butte and the Upper Loop circles Black Butte. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: TBD

BikingTrails.name: Sparks Lake/lava Lakes
BikingTrails.description: Trails are Pavement and Dirt (10.0 mi. single track, 13.5 mi. pavement). This is a challenging ride for a beginner who should be in good shape and prepared to ride over some rough rocks. The scenery is beautiful as the trail winds its way through forests of lodgepole pine. The described route returns along the highway but you can return the way you came if you choose.
BikingTrails.directions: Drive 25 miles west of Bend on Hwy 46 (Cascade Lakes Hwy) to Sparks Lake. Turn left toward Sparks Lake and follow the road to your left 0.1 mile to the Sparks Lake Trail trailhead on your left and park here.

BikingTrails.name: Deer Lake Trailhead
BikingTrails.description: This trailhead offers parking north of Little Cultus Lake.
BikingTrails.directions: From Bend, travel 46.0 miles southwest on Cascade Lakes Hwy (46), then 0.8 miles west on Forest Road 4635, then 1.7 miles southwest on Forest Road 4630, then 0.7 miles southwest on Forest Road 4636, and then about 0.3 miles northwest on Forest Road 4636-640.

BikingTrails.name: Quinn Creek Trail
BikingTrails.description: This short trail follows the lovely spring-fed Quinn Creek past the north end of Hosmer Lake and on to the Metolius-Windigo Horse Trail. With only a short shuttle by bike or car between Sparks and Devil's Lake, a nice 11-mile loop can be made by connecting the Katsuk Pond Trail #13 from Devils Lake Trailhead to Quinn Creek, and then on to Sparks Lake via the Metolius-Windigo Horse Trail. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: This trail is most easily accessed at Quinn Meadow Horse Camp, a reservation only campground, 31 miles west of Bend out Century Drive.  Hikers can park near the gate on the highway and walk in to access the trailhead and other trails.

BikingTrails.name: Field's Creek / Trail #212
BikingTrails.description: This trail provides access to Fields Peak, elevation 7362', and McClellan Mountain Trail #216. The McClellan Mountain Semi-Primitive Non-Motorized area is adjacent to the Fields Peak Trail. via fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: From John Day, travel west on US Highway 26 for approximately 18 miles to Forest Service Road (FSR) 21. Drive south on Forest Service Road 21 for approximately 8 miles to Forest Service Road 2100115. There will be a sign along the road indicating the direction to McClellan Trailhead. Drive east on Forest Service Road 2100115 for 1/4 mile to Forest Service Road 2160. Drive south on Forest Service Road 2160 for a short distance to Forest Service Road 2160041. Continue driving south on Forest Service Road 2160041 to the trailhead. Parking is available to several passenger vehicles and stock trailers.

BikingTrails.name: Suttle Lake Loop
BikingTrails.description: The loop is about 2 miles approximately in length and the highway side of the lake is less congested as several campgrounds border the opposite side.  The best part of this trail is not the loop around the lake however but the ride slightly descending from Suttle Lake that connects you to Black Butte Loop trails near the Sherman Camp turn-off of hwy 22.  This part of the trail is called the Suttle Lake Tie trail.  It rides very fast and winds through beautiful woodland.  The first mile nearest the lake does get pretty tight with dense shrubbery whacking at you so maneuver carefully.  The trail is quite smooth and very negotiable for beginners nonetheless.  A few sandy areas might trip you up in a few spots during dry months.  Since I was staying at Suttle Lake at the time I just traveled the trail to the connection point of the Black Butte Loops and then back again.  The descent from Suttle Lake was gradual enough that the return trip was only slightly more difficult.   I definitely will be coming back to explore further.  From the Sherman Creek turnoff and Black Butte Loops you can also connect to a trail that takes you to Sisters.  I will be back to experience those trails soon.
BikingTrails.directions: Drive into the Suttle Lake area off of hwy 22 between the Hoodoo summit and Sisters.  The trail loops around the lake and you can access it from any of the campgrounds around the lake.

BikingTrails.name: Riley Creek / Trail #216A
BikingTrails.description: This trail travels along Riley Creek and provides access to McClellan Mountain Trail #216.  Parking is limited to passenger vehicles. via fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: From John Day, take US Highway 395 to County road 63. On County road 63, go west approximately 6 miles to Forest Service road 21. Take the 21 road to the junction of Forest Service road 2190. The trailhead is located at the end of the 2190 road.

BikingTrails.name: Lemish Lake Trail
BikingTrails.description: Overall, this is a good mountain bike trail, especially as a loop via Clover Meadow Trail No. 21 & Clover-Lemish Tie No. 18.  The side trip to Lily Lake is a highlight, though it is best done on foot due to steep and wet terrain.From Lemish Lake Trailhead to the junction of Charlton Lake Trail No. 19 at Forest Road 4290, this trail passes through lovely meadows and a variety of forest types.  Early season mosquitoes can be fierce in this area. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: Take Forest Road 40 about 26 miles west of Sunriver, continue on Forest Road 4630 to Little Cultus Lake. Take Forest Road 4736 a short distance to the Lemish Lake Trailhead.  Alternate access is from Forest Road 4290 near Charlton Lake.

BikingTrails.name: Myrtle Creek / Trail #308
BikingTrails.description: This trail follows along Myrtle Creek through a pretty, gentle river canyon with ponderosa pine and creekside vegetation. One way trail ends at private land. Must go down and back. via fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: From Burns, travel north on US Highway 395 approximately 16 miles to Forest Service road 31. Travel 15 miles west on the 31 road to Forest Service road 3100226. The trailhead is located at the edge of the road.

BikingTrails.name: Round Meadow Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail ascends gradually from Forest Road 4290 to the junction of the Charlton Lake Trail #19, and passes through diverse forests and meadow habitats.  Early season mosquitoes can be mean. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: The trail begins approximately 33 miles west of Sunriver and a few miles east of Charlton Lake. The trailhead is 4 miles west of Hwy 46 (Century Drive) on Forest Road 4290, where the Clover Meadow Trail #21 and Round Meadow Trail meet the road from the north and south, respectively.  Road 4290 is often quite rough, especially beyond the trailheads.

BikingTrails.name: Clover Meadow Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail begins at Forest Road 4290, passes the Clover-Lemish Tie Trail #18, and continues on to the junction of the Lemish Lake Trail #19.2 and Lily Lake Trail #19.3 junction.  source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: This trail is found near Little Cultus Lake roughly 30 miles west of Sunriver. The trail is reached via the Clover Meadow Trail #21 from the Johnny Lake Trailhead on Forest Road 4290 or Lemish Lake Trail #19.2 from the Lemish Lake Trailhead on Forest Road 4636.

BikingTrails.name: Moore Creek Trail
BikingTrails.description: The trailhead is located on Forest Road 6452-600.  The trail leads west past Bobby Lake to end at the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail #2000.  This gentle trail passes through lodgepole pine, mountain hemlock, and noble fir.  There is an excellent view of Maiden Peak at Bobby Lake.
BikingTrails.directions: TDB

BikingTrails.name: Maiden Lake Trail
BikingTrails.description: The trailhead is located at end of Forest Road 4664-100, and goes west to join the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail #2000 near Rosary Lake. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: TBD

BikingTrails.name: Maiden Peak Trail
BikingTrails.description: This trail begins from the Maiden Lake Trail #41 and goes to the summit of Maiden Peak.  A trail continues west from the summit of Maiden Peak to the Pacific Crest National Scenic Trail #2000 on the Willamette National Forest.  Benches and a lava flow will be encountered before this trail junctions with the Maiden Peak Trail from Gold Lake. source: fs.usda.gov
BikingTrails.directions: Located off NF-4664 west of La Pine.

BikingTrails.name: Timothy Lake Trail
BikingTrails.description: Going clockwise, it starts out as a rolling, swooping single track.  Fir needles, a few roots, nice.  After you walk your bike two hundred yards on the Pacific Crest Trail, the trail changes to more rocky single track with steeper pitches. You cross a few roads, but there isn't much traffic up there.  The part around Clackamas Lake is pretty easy--very dusty in late summer.  The latter part of the ride on the east side of Timothy Lake has a few technical spots, but nothing too serious.  Come out on forest road 57, cross the dam, and you're done. The trail itself can be a good workout for beginners and experience in riding the trail will vary whether you ride it clockwise or counter-clockwise.
BikingTrails.directions: Park near the Timothy Lake Dam.  $5 daily fee.

BikingTrails.name: Cedar Creek/15-Mile
BikingTrails.description: While Cedar Creek and 15-Mile parallel each other coursing down opposite sides of the Fifteen Mile Creek, they are not typical river trails and, instead, require a steep and sustained climbing effort. The two trails share a common pathway for the initial 0.5 miles which then forks high atop either side of the creek's ravine and continue downhill to create an inverse elevation profile. Either direction you choose, you're going down right out the gate with a grueling climb back to the car.Perched 2,000 feet above the creek, both trails sweep opposite sides of the ravine's steep slope diving and stretching deeper and further into the firmament. Ancient volcanic rock fields stationed on exposed cliffside guard the eastern Oregon expanse almost as if it were Mother Nature's personal watchtower. The ground is a perfect medley of rock, root, needle-pack, volcanic moondust, and black gold. I think loam actually sums it up nicely. The Cedar Creek descent ends with a sharp ridge descent over such an amount of pumice and baby head, I hardly recognized any evidence of a trail before popping back onto clay at Fifteen Mile Creek's river bottom. The initial climb out on the 15-Mile trail begins easy enough, but shortly after the mellow grade ascent, we were met with long stretches of hillside hike-a-bike punctuated by more outcroppings of rock. Once back on top, the trail continues climbing in earnest, but can be done so pedaling all the way back to the car.
BikingTrails.directions: From Hood River, drive 26 miles to the National Forest Development Rd. 44. Turn east up 44 for 5 miles and turn right onto Dufur Valley Rd. In another 3 miles on Dufur you'll pass the Knebal Springs/8-Mile Trailhead and your next right will be onto Cold Springs Rd. Four miles in on Cold Springs, you'll see a campground and the Fifteen Mile Creek. Parking is limited and you must have a Northwest Forest Pass.

BikingTrails.name: Fifteen Mile Creek
BikingTrails.description: The trailhead is right in the campground by the outhouse...go down this trail for about 1/2 mile or so...then turn right accross the river...the trail then goes down for about 5 miles or so...some parts are very fast...some technical...but very good single track...one of the best stretches of downhill that i've ever done...but all that fun downhill turns to uphill when you reach the bottom...this is probably the toughest 6 miles of climbing i've ever done...but for some reason i find myself going back to this trail because the downhill is so AWESOME!!..this trail is used mostly on the weekends because it is so far away from everything...so if you go out during the week make sure someone knows where you are...i've been out there during the week and haven't seen a sole.
BikingTrails.directions: From I-84 east in Hood River, take exit 64 for Highway 35.  Turn right towards Government Camp.  Go about 25ish miles on hwy 35 to Dufur Mill Road (FR 44).  Turn left and go approx 9 miles to 4420.  Turn right on 4420 and go about 2 miles.  Turn left at junction on 2730...Campground will be on the left.

BikingTrails.name: Klamath Wild and Scenic River
BikingTrails.description: Trails great for mountain biking.

BikingTrails.name: Gunsight Ridge
BikingTrails.description: Gunsight Ridge can be used to create an 18.7-mile loop with stunning views of Mount Hood
BikingTrails.directions: OR

BikingTrails.name: 8 Mile Loop/ Tr #459
BikingTrails.description: Leaving Bottle Prairie this trail heads downhill for a 2.5 mile, very fast singletrack ride through the forest along eightmile cr. Although there is a lot of downed trees in the area I didnâ€™t find any across the trail, but stay alert, its easy to gain a lot of speed on this section. At the junction with Eightmile crossing (start option #2) proceed left, at this point you will re-acquaint yourself with 1st, 2nd and maybe 3rd gears once again as the trail climbs about 900â€™ via switchbacks in the next 1.5 miles. Once on top of the ridge you will run across a short spur to the R that leads to t he base of a fire lookout station at 4627â€™, a great spot for a break. Back on the main trail youâ€™ll have .5 miles of fast downhill before crossing a F.S. rd and a bit more climbing before the final mile of single track back to Bottle Prairie.This a great singletrack trail that is well maintained and obviously a popular route for the locals here. Please ride with respect.
BikingTrails.directions: Start option #1- Turn South on Highway 35 from Hood River, turn L on road 44. Follow rd 44 6 miles and turn L into Bottle Prairie TH, (this is a very small rd and easy to miss) cross cr and park. Singletrack starts right next to cr and heads downstream. Start option #2- Continue on rd 44 another 3 miles to the well marked Eightmile campground on the L, as you near the campground ground park in the lot near the 1st outhouse. There is a sign there marking the TH indicating â€˜clockwiseâ€™ to be the preferred direction of travel- maybe so for hikers but this trail report was written in a â€˜counter-clockwiseâ€™ direction. Continue up the trail .3 miles across a road and to a junction with the main trail.

BikingTrails.name: Lookout Mountain Trail/#450
BikingTrails.description: An OAB that features almost nonstop climbing on the way out and fast downhill fun on the way back. Nothing too technical, but plenty of roots and some of the climbing is steep enough to test your fortitude.  Can be tied into Fifteen Mile Creek trail for a strenuous 20 mile journey.
BikingTrails.directions: Take Highway 44 east off Highway 35 approximately 8 miles. The TH is directly across the road from the TH for 8 Mile Loop/Tr. #459 and Knebel Springs Trail.

BikingTrails.name: Lookout Mountain Trail/#450
BikingTrails.description: An OAB that features almost nonstop climbing on the way out and fast downhill fun on the way back. Nothing too technical, but plenty of roots and some of the climbing is steep enough to test your fortitude.  Can be tied into Fifteen Mile Creek trail for a strenuous 20 mile journey.
BikingTrails.directions: Take Highway 44 east off Highway 35 approximately 8 miles. The TH is directly across the road from the TH for 8 Mile Loop/Tr. #459 and Knebel Springs Trail.

BikingTrails.name: Pioneer Bridle
BikingTrails.description: Start on the glade trail from just south west of the main lodge. Its rocky single track. Follow to the Crosstown trail a little more mellow dirt. Then merge with the pioneer bridle trail some steep down hill with some switch backs packed dirt and some rocky areas. It brings you to hwy 26 cross hwy and continue on trail to camp ground.
BikingTrails.directions: From Sandy head east on hwy 26 to timberline lodge.

BikingTrails.name: Timberline Bike Park
BikingTrails.description: Green, blue, and black trails are open in Phase I, opened August 2019. There is a 4.5-mile-long green trail.
BikingTrails.directions: At the Timberline Lodge and Ski Area.

BikingTrails.name: Timberline to Town
BikingTrails.description: 95% downhill, flowy, rugged, very dusty when dry. Good signage along the first half of the trail. Latter half you'll just turn on whatever trail points you most downhill. You'll eventually be dumped out onto highway where you cross and follow the singletrack that parallels the highway all the way back to Rhododendron.
BikingTrails.directions: From Portland, take I-84 East. Exit 16 Wood Village heading South. Turn left (east) on NE Burnside Rd. This turns into Mt. Hood Highway. Follow to Rhododendron and park car where you can shuttle to Timberline Lodge at the base of Mount Hood or catch the Mt. Hood Express transit bus. It's $2 to Timberline resort.

BikingTrails.name: Mount Hood Ski Bowl
BikingTrails.description: Just down the street from Mount Hood, adjacent to the Village of Government Camp, is Ski Bowl-a 1,500 vertical-foot, ski lift-assisted bike park. While the small resort may not top any recent consumer lists, Ski Bowl is no slouch, proving its worth as host to two of seven Northwest Cup DH races this year. With new additions and upgrades appearing year after year, coupled with Portland mountain bikers' deep desire for gravity-assisted riding, Ski Bowl maintains a slow-but-steady course in becoming something truly great. -Chris Daniels
BikingTrails.directions: OR

BikingTrails.name: Surveyor's Ridge
BikingTrails.description: Flow & views
BikingTrails.directions: Trail head

BikingTrails.name: Knebal Springs Trail #474
BikingTrails.description: Knebal Springs Trail #474 is a 3.99 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Cooks Meadow Trail/ #639
BikingTrails.description: Climbing begins immediately and doesn't stop until the almost the top of the ride.  Thankfully not technical but a total grind.  Of course, the return trip is a blast though you have to watch your speed as the trail is quite narrow and not a berm along the way.
BikingTrails.directions: Take Road 44 off of Highway 35; travel approximately 3 miles to Surveyors Ridge/Dog River trail shared TH (look or sign). Ride the first 1.5 beautiful miles of the Surveyors Ridge trail. Cooks Meadow trail begins just before the first wooden bridge. Look for sign on the right.

BikingTrails.name: 44 Trail System
BikingTrails.description: Trail system includes Surveyor's, Dog River, Eight Mile, and Knebal trails.
BikingTrails.directions: Many trailheads, most accessible off Hwy 35.

BikingTrails.name: Dog River Trail
BikingTrails.description: Beautiful forest ride with glimpses of Mount Hood.  Unless you have a shuttle the rewards are hard earned.  Plenty of climbing or descent depending on your direction.  Just a few technical areas plus a few swithchbacks; otherwise a straightforward ride.  Shared TH with Surveyors Ridge Trail.
BikingTrails.directions: From either Government Camp or Hood River take Highway 35. Travel 16 miles from GC or 26 miles from HR before turning onto National Forest Road 44. Travel just over 3 miles to find a shared TH with Surveyor's Ridge trail (there is a sign).

BikingTrails.name: Deschutes River - Harrison Ranch
BikingTrails.description: This is an old railroad bed that is a double-track trail.  Small rocks, sand, a few climbs.  Pretty easy ride along the river.  Old box cars up toward the old, Harrison Ranch.  You can camp up there if you like.  I've seen mountain sheep, deer and other minor critters up there.  Bring a flat-tire kit or/and extra tube... lots of goatheads.
BikingTrails.directions: From Portland, take I-84 east.  Go past Hood River toward Celilo Village. Take exit for Deschutes River Recreation Area. Turn left at end of ramp; follow signs (about 2 miles) to entrance. Trailhead is up the bank at back of parking area.

BikingTrails.name: Old Salmon River Trail
BikingTrails.description: TRAIL IS MODERATE AND GOES ALONG THE RIVER IN PARTS. MILI HAD FUN rnSWIMMING IN THE RIVER EVEN THOUGH IT WAS VERY COLD.
BikingTrails.directions: From Portland drive east on US Highway 26 for approximately 42 miles.  In Welches,  turn right onto Old Salmon River Road [forest service 2618] and proceed 2.3 miles to the trailhead on your right.

BikingTrails.name: Military Road Trail
BikingTrails.description: Military Road Trail is a 0.88 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Entry Road Trail
BikingTrails.description: Entry Road Trail is a 0.37 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Vista Loop Trail
BikingTrails.description: Vista Loop Trail is a 3.04 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Eightmile Alternate Trail
BikingTrails.description: Eightmile Alternate Trail is a 1.04 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Columbia Hills Historical State Park
BikingTrails.description: Columbia Hills Historical State Park features 10 miles of smooth, flowy grassland riding. There are also many great viewpoints of Mount Hood and the Columbia River.
BikingTrails.directions: From Dallesport, head north on the Dalles-California Highway (US 197) to its junction with the Lewis and Clark Highway (WA 14). Turn right onto WA 14, and eventually the Dalles Mountain Road will appear on the left. Take it, and the trailhead will soon appear to the left.

BikingTrails.name: Whoopdee
BikingTrails.description: Most enjoy Whoopdee riding counter-clockwise. Ride 0.25 miles south on gravel road where singletrack starts off left. The Whoopdee trail is a great mix of flowy, undulating track with short climbs (except for the climb out) and fast descents. Towards the bottom of the loop, there are a series of fast roller coaster-like drops followed by immediate steep climbs. There's nothing incredibly technical and beginner's can enjoy this trail too. The climb out to the parking lot is about 30 minutes of singletrack switchback to the parking lot. NOTE: this land is owned by Stevenson Land Company who has graciously allowed non-motorized use so it behooves the rider to be on their best behavior when riding. From time to time, the trail will close for logging and some sections may be closed or re-routed. Check out www.hrats.org (Hood River Area Trail Stewards) for updates.
BikingTrails.directions: From Eastside Rd in Hood River, drive up Old Dalles Rd and turn right onto Elder Rd. The Whoopdee Trailhead has an obvious parking lot with signs on the right of Elder Rd.

BikingTrails.name: Klickitat River Trail
BikingTrails.description: The trail follows along the Klickitat River for 10 miles.  The trail is a mixture of single track and double track with a mixture of crushed gravel, bigger, rocky gravel.  The singletrack portions of the trail are legitimately fun for beginner mountain bikers who learn to roll over rocks (or dodge them) and learn basic mountain bike skills.  Cows from the local farms may sometimes inhabit the trails, so bring a bike bell.
BikingTrails.directions: Trailhead starts at a parking lot in the west end of the town of Lyle, Washington. From Vancouver, WA, drive east along SR-14. Once reaching Lyle, cross a short bridge spanning over the Klickitat River, and turn left onto State Route 142. Parking lot is immediately on the left.

BikingTrails.name: Syncline
BikingTrails.description: Network of single track with many ride options. Take one up and another down.  Can connect to coyote cliffs and hospital hill
BikingTrails.directions: 3 miles east of Bingen Washington Take hwy 14, (across the river from Hood River Oregon). Park at the base of Courtney road. Ride east for 1/3 mile, around the base of the syncline cliffs and start climbing up the many zig zag trails that climb the slope on the left

BikingTrails.name: Little Maui Trail
BikingTrails.description: Little Maui Trail is a 1.3 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Little Moab Trail
BikingTrails.description: Little Moab Trail is a 0.57 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Loose Lucy trail
BikingTrails.description: Loose Lucy trail is a 1.56 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Hidden Canyon Trail
BikingTrails.description: Hidden Canyon Trail is a 1.85 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Old Ranch Road
BikingTrails.description: Old Ranch Road is a 2.67 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Crybaby Trail
BikingTrails.description: Crybaby Trail is a 1.19 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Golden Eagle Bike Park
BikingTrails.description: Skills area, progressive jump lines, and pump track.
BikingTrails.directions: Off Indian Creek Rd, near the intersection with Hwy 281.

BikingTrails.name: Indian Creek (Lower)
BikingTrails.description: Wide open trail with multiple entrance points throughout Hood River.  The trail follows along the water drainage and the lower section hits Hazel road near down town and then winds up to around 12th and Pacific.  You must cross the road at this point where the trail opens on the south side and is more grassy/muddy.  You eventually hit a sign where the trail stops due to private property.  There is a Upper portion of the trail but they do not connect but are labeled as the same trail.<This trail is excellent for quick MTB, walking, hiking and trail running when you do not have much time.Not technical at all and way to short for a good ride but if thats all you can get it is one to consider.
BikingTrails.directions: Serpentine road to hazel and there is a trail sign on the right. No real parking.

BikingTrails.name: Hospital Hill
BikingTrails.description: Network of mostly singletrack trails with 2500+ feet of elevation gain, from floor of the Gorge to top of the ridge. Options include steep, tight switchbacks, long climbs in your granniest of all gears, great downhill runs, fantastic view from the top of the Gorge and Mt Hood. Sections also include quite a bit of exposure. Often have to cross fences, keep an eye out for hikers and other bikers coming back. For advanced riders only. Complete quess on the trail length.
BikingTrails.directions: Starts off of NE Skyline Dr. Take Hwy 14 to E Oak St in Bingen, WA to E Jewett Blvd, to NE Skyline Dr.

BikingTrails.name: BMX Track
BikingTrails.description: BMX Track is a 0.19 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Freeride Track
BikingTrails.description: Freeride Track is a 0.87 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: White Salmon Mountain Bike Park
BikingTrails.description: This small park features a pump track, a couple jump lines, and access to the much larger Hospital Hill trail system.
BikingTrails.directions: From eastbound Route 141 (East Jewett Blvd) in White Salmon, turn left onto Northeast Estes Avenue in downtown. Then, immediately turn right onto Northeast Tohomish Street. The park will soon appear on your left across from the Jewett Sports Complex.

BikingTrails.name: Post Canyon
BikingTrails.description: By many accounts, Post Canyon has some of the most radical freeride action in the northwest. Because it is not on more regulated national forest land, locals were able to build extensive wooden features. The first mile and a half or so are on private land. Then it turns into State Park land and at the upper end it is Hood River County Forest land.The lower section climbs gradually along a small meandering stream crossing back and forth over it 7 times, (which is how the Seven Streams trail got it's name). Up top, there are mind blowing wooden stunts built for experts, and a really fun practice area for learning called Family Man. After the climbing effort is over, your reward is 4 miles of smooth, twisty,  screaming single-track all the way home.You can ride Post Canyon as an out & back, or connect up several trails to make a super fun loop ride. It rides best clockwise.
BikingTrails.directions: Follow Post Canyon road out of Hood. River township. Once it becomes dirt, you will see the trailhead.

BikingTrails.name: Flume Creek
BikingTrails.description: Several trails in the Family Man Staging Area including Trail #100, Trail #145, and Trail #116.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Wyeth/Trail #400
BikingTrails.description: A narrow out-and-back singletrack that is a continuous gentle climb on the way out and a nice roll downhill on the way back.  Dense tree canopy for the most part there are a few open sections that provide views of the Columbia River. Nothing too technical but some rocks, roots and small water crossings.  A good place for a beginner work on stamina and climbing skills.
BikingTrails.directions: Exit # 51 (east or west) I-84. The Wyeth Campground is just off the end of the ramps (away from the river).

BikingTrails.name: Nestor 26
BikingTrails.description: HRATS is currently working to revitalize this rugged trail system.
BikingTrails.directions: A couple parking spots located along Buck Creek Rd.

BikingTrails.name: Echo Hills Vinyard Mtb Trail System
BikingTrails.description: Classic dessert single track in Eastern Oregon. Near Original Oregon Trail site.  Trail is ride able almost all year round. Maintained by Echo Hills Trail builders an IMBA club.
BikingTrails.directions: Take I-84 to the Echo/Lexington Exit 193; turn left at the stop sign. Follow the signs to Echoâ€”about 4 miles. Turn right at the first stop sign in Echo (right turn without stopping), go Â¼ mile and turn leftâ€”over the RR tracks and into downtown ECHOâ€¦Stay on the main drag through Echo (there is no sign to downtown, but it's left on Main Street, the road toward Lexington), cross the Umatilla River and Westland Irrigation Canal (total distance is about 1 mile) until you reach the top of the hill---turn left on Snow Road (gravel). The total distance from downtown ECHO to Snow Rd is about one mile. Go left (south) on Snow Rd for about 1.6 miles until you come to a WINDMILL on your leftâ€”turn left on the gravel road next to the WINDMILL (east). Follow this gravel road for about 0.7 miles (there will be several rock pits on the right and a pheasant hunting club sign on your left) and at the bottom of the hill, turn right through the gate. The parking lot is here and the Trail Signs are up and easily visible (A Trail).

BikingTrails.name: easyCLIMB
BikingTrails.description: Trail consists of twisty single track with some moderate climbs. Clay is the predominant trail surface with a few rocky sections. Designed to be family friendly, it's a great trail to take the kids on.
BikingTrails.directions: Find it by driving east through downtown Cascade Locks. Get on Forest Lane and watch for signs to Easy Climb Trail. If driving east on I-84 into town, watch for Forest Lane soon after you exit the freeway.

BikingTrails.name: Moore Park Trail Network
BikingTrails.description: A growing network of purposely built mountain bike trails(although there are quite a few hikers and runners on them, so be aware).  If starting at the gravel TH, head north from parking lot and around green gate.  Trails branch from this main gravel road on the right and left.  A map is available from Hutch's Bike shop on Klamath Ave.

BikingTrails.name: Buck Creek Trail
BikingTrails.description: Buck Creek Trail is a 3.25 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Monte Carlo (#52)
BikingTrails.description: This route takes you from the junction of Monte Carlo Trail (#52) and Monte Cristo Trail (#53) to the summit of Monte Carlo. Monte Carlo Trail does continue west off of the summit down towards Oklahoma Road.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Monte Cristo (#53)
BikingTrails.description: Monte Cristo (#53) starts on the ridge on its namesake and drops down towards the Little White Salmon River. Parking is scarce at the lower trailhead.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Lake Wallula State Park
BikingTrails.description: Lake Wallula State Park is located in northeastern Oregon and southeastern Washington. It is located at the site of the McNary Dam and offers hiking, mountain biking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.
BikingTrails.directions: One mile east of Umatilla, OR, on Highway 730, and take the McNary Dam Road.

BikingTrails.name: McClellan Meadows Trail #157
BikingTrails.description: McClellan Meadows Trail #157 is a 3.4 mile mountain bike trail.
BikingTrails.directions: See map.

BikingTrails.name: Falls Creek
BikingTrails.description: Ride thru deep forest. Heavy moss on some of the trees. Trail ends back at the highway lower and to the south of start after paralleling a river. Highly scenic.
BikingTrails.directions: North from Carson on WA 30 to pass. Singletrack to the east.
